questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents with a two-month history of persistent itching, redness, and scaling of the right nipple, unresponsive to moisturizing creams. Physical examination reveals erythema and crusting of the nipple and areola without palpable breast lumps. The image of her right breast is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Paget disease of the nipple
questions.explanation:
Finding

Description

Possible Cause

Nipple discharge

Discharge from a single duct orifice

Papilloma (Option C) or other underlying ductal disease

Paget disease of the nipple

Appears as a psoriatic rash starting on the nipple and spreading to the areola and breast skin.

Paget disease

Skin dimpling
  • Traction on Cooper ligaments by a scirrhous tumor
  • Best seen with angled indirect lighting during the abduction of the arms upward.

Scirrhous tumor (Option B)

Peau d’orange (skin of the orange)

Edema of the breast skin
  • Inflammatory carcinoma (Option D)
  • Lymphatic blockage
  • Mastitis

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman diagnosed with early-stage breast cancer opts for surgery that involves the removal of the entire breast, including the nipple and areola, but not the axillary lymph nodes. Which type of mastectomy is she likely undergoing?
questions.explanation:
Types

Structures removed

Simple/Total mastectomy (Option A)

En bloc removal of

  • Nipple
  • Areola
  • Breast mass
  • Skin

Extended mastectomy (Total Mastectomy with Axillary Dissection) (Option D)

Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes

Halsted/Radical mastectomy (Option C)

Simple mastectomy + removal of level I, II, III axillary lymph nodes + excision of pectoralis major and minor muscle.

Modified Radical Mastectomy(MRM) (Option B)

Simple mastectomy + removal of level I, II, III axillary lymph nodes

 

Variants :

  • Auchincloss modification : MRM
  • Patey’s modification: MRM + excision of pectoralis minor
  • Scanlons modification: MRM + division of pectoralis minor(removal and resuturing)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not an absolute contraindication for breast-conserving surgery (BCS)?

options.label: A
options.text: Prior radiation therapy to the chest wall or breast

questions.explanation:
Absolute Contraindications
  • Pregnancy (Option D ruled out) because after BCS postop radiotherapy will be necessary which is not possible in case pregnancy.
  • Multicentric Disease
  • Diffuse malignant microcalcifications on mammogram suggests widespread disease, making complete excision with clear margins unlikely (Option B ruled out)
  • Prior Radiation Therapy to the Chest Wall or Breast  cannot give radiation again, which is essential after BCS(Option A ruled out)
  • Extensive Positive Pathological Margins

Relative Contraindications
  • Active Connective Tissue Disease Involving the Skin (e.g., Scleroderma)
  • Large tumor size relative to breast size or tumors greater than 5 cm
  • Large pendulous breast
  • Centrally located tumor
  • Extensive DCIS (often requires aggressive management, such as mastectomy, due to the risk of recurrence).
  • Homozygous for ATM Mutation
  • Known or Suspected Li-Fraumeni Syndrome (p53 Mutation)
  • Known or Suspected Genetic Predisposition to Breast Cancer (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2) - Prophylactic mastectomy is preferred for individuals with high genetic cancer risk to reduce the likelihood of developing breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following are components of the Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) for DCIS? Tumor size Margin status Histological grade Patient age
questions.explanation:
Factor

Score 1

Score 2

Score 3

Tumor Size

≤ 15 mm

16-40 mm

>40 mm

Margin Status

>10 mm

1-9 mm

<1 mm

Histological Grade
  • Grade I/II
  • Well-differentiated
  • Necrosis absent
  • Grade I/II
  • Moderately differentiated
  • Necrosis present
  • Grade III
  • Poorly differentiated
  • Necrosis present

Patient Age

> 61 years

40-60 years

< 39 years

questions.text: Which of the following describes the basal type of breast malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Subtype

ER Status

PR Status

HER2 Status

Ki-67 Status

Characteristics

Luminal A

+

+

-

Low

Generally low grade, better prognosis, responsive to hormonal therapy.

Luminal B

+

+ or -

+ or -

High

Higher grade, poor prognosis compared to Luminal A, may require targeted HER2 therapy following status.

HER2-enriched

-

-

+

High

Aggressive, higher grade, poor prognosis, requires targeted HER2 therapy.

Basal-like

-

-

-

High

Includes triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), highly aggressive, no targeted hormonal therapy.

Claudin-low

-

-

+ or -

Often High

Often associated with poor prognosis and aggressive behavior, typically lacks response to hormonal therapy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a palpable breast lump. After imaging studies and a biopsy, the results show a tumor measuring 3.5 cm in the breast. The patient also has involvement of ipsilateral internal mammary lymph nodes, but no distant metastases are detected. Based on the TNM staging system, what is the appropriate stage for this breast cancer?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Description

Tumor size (T)

TX

Primary tumor cannot be assessed

T0

No evidence of primary tumor

Tis

Carcinoma in situ (DCIS, LCIS, or Paget's disease)

T1

Tumor ≤ 2 cm

T1mi

Tumor ≤ 1 mm

T1a

Tumor > 1 mm but ≤ 5 mm

T1b

Tumor > 5 mm but ≤ 10 mm

T1c

Tumor > 10 mm but ≤ 20 mm

T2

Tumor > 2 cm but ≤ 5 cm

T3

Tumor > 5 cm

T4

Tumor of any size with direct extension to chest wall or skin

T4a

Extension to chest wall

T4b

Ulceration or skin nodules

T4c

Both T4a and T4b

T4d

Inflammatory breast cancer

Node (N)

NX

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastases to movable ipsilateral level I, II axillary lymph nodes

N2

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes or clinically apparent internal mammary nodes

N2a

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes that are clinically fixed or matted

N2b

Metastasis to internal mammary nodes without axillary lymph node involvement

N3

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes or infraclavicular nodes, or to supraclavicular nodes

N3a

Metastasis to infraclavicular nodes

N3b

Metastasis to internal mammary nodes

N3c

Metastasis to supraclavicular nodes

Metastasis (M)

MX

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis present

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents for her routine mammogram. She has no family history of breast cancer and no previous history of breast issues. A mammogram reveals a well-circumscribed, homogeneous lesion with characteristic benign features, such as a simple cyst with no suspicious calcifications or architectural distortions. Based on these findings, What is the appropriate BI-RADS category for this lesion?
questions.explanation:
BI-RADS Category

Description

Management

Likelihood of Malignancy

0

Incomplete

Need additional imaging evaluation

N/A

1

Negative

Routine screening

Essentially 0%

2

Benign

Routine screening

Essentially 0%

3

Probably Benign

Short-term follow-up (6 months)

< 2%

4

Suspicious of Malignancy

Biopsy should be considered

  

4A

Suspicious: Low

_

> 2% to ≤ 10%

4B

Suspicious: Moderate

_

> 10% to ≤ 50%

4C

Suspicious: High

_

> 50% to ≤ 95%

5

Highly Suggestive of Malignancy

Appropriate action should be taken

> 95%

6

Known Biopsy-Proven Malignancy

Appropriate action should be taken

100%

questions.text: Match the following: Biopsy Feature 1. FNAC a. Evaluation of cellular fibroadenoma 2. Core-needle biopsy b. Assessment of suspicious lymph nodes 3. Excisional biopsy c. Sampling solid masses, calcifications, and densities identified on imaging
questions.explanation:
Biopsy Type

Description

Indications

Limitations

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA)

22-gauge needle
  • Evaluation of secondaries
  • Assessment of suspicious lymph nodes
  • Cannot differentiate between noninvasive and invasive lesions if malignant cells are found
  • Requires core needle biopsy (CNB) for definitive histologic diagnosis
  • May yield inconclusive results

Core Needle Biopsy (CNB)
  • Preferred method
  • Imaging guidance
  • Needle: 8 to 14-gauge
  • Sampling solid masses, calcifications, and densities identified on imaging
  • Used to obtain histologic subtype, grade, and receptor status of detected malignancies
  • Small sample size requires careful interpretation
  • Inconclusive results may necessitate surgical excision

Excisional Biopsy
  • Entire lesion removed for diagnosis
  • Used when CNB results are inconclusive or when there is discordance with imaging findings
  • Evaluation of atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) or cellular fibroadenoma
  • Costly
  • Delays definitive treatment
  • More invasive

questions.text: A 48-year-old female underwent a lumpectomy for a 2 cm invasive ductal carcinoma in her right breast. Post-surgery pathology revealed positive margins, indicating residual cancerous tissue. Which of the following investigations is most suitable to check for residual cancer tissues?
questions.explanation:
Uses
  • Determines if a lesion detected by mammography is solid or cystic
  • Discriminating lesions in dense breasts

Limitations
  • Not effective as a standalone breast cancer screening tool
  • Highly dependent on the operator performing the scan
  • Lack of standardized screening protocols

questions.text: A lesion was found in a routine mammogram of a 52-year-old asymptomatic woman. Which of the following statements regarding mammogram findings is false?

options.label: A
options.text: If the density of the lesion is high, it is mostly malignant

options.label: B
options.text: Architectural distortion is usually present in benign lesions

options.label: C
options.text: Calcification in benign lesions is diffuse

options.label: D
options.text: Margins are well-circumscribed in benign lesions

questions.correct_answer: B. Architectural distortion is usually present in benign lesions
questions.explanation:
Feature

Benign Lesions

Malignant Lesions

Shape

Round, oval, lobular

Irregular

Margins

Circumscribed

Microlobulated, obscured, indistinct, spiculated

Density

Low to intermediate

Intermediate to high

Distribution of Calcifications

Randomly distributed, diffuse

Grouped, clustered, fine linear, branching, segmental

Architectural Distortion

Usually absent

Often present

Purpose of Screening

Detect occult breast cancer in asymptomatic women

Benefits
  • Early detection
  • Reduced mortality
  • High sensitivity and specificity in older women (fatty breast tissue)

Disadvantages

  • Screening expenses
  • False positives
  • Additional workups
  • Anxiety

(USPSTF) Recommendations
  • Biennial screening for women 50-74 years
  • Recommended against screening for women 40-49 years and >75 years.

American Cancer Society Recommendations
  • Annual screening for women >40 years in good health
  • MRI screening for younger women with high risk (20% lifetime risk)

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a painless lump in her right breast, noticed during a self-examination two weeks ago. Which of the following tests has the maximum accuracy?
questions.explanation:
1. Clinical Examination

Objective: Identify lumps, skin changes, nipple discharge, or lymphadenopathy.

Procedure: Palpation of breasts and lymph nodes.

2. Imaging

Methods:

  • Mammography: Preferred for women over 40.
  • Ultrasound: Used in younger women or for further evaluation.

3. Biopsy

Types:

  • FNA: Minimally invasive; used for cystic lesions.
  • Core Needle: Preferred for solid masses.
  • Excisional: Removes lump for examination.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about lymphatic drainage of the breast is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Level III lymph nodes are located lateral to the pectoralis minor muscle.

options.label: B
options.text: Lymphatic drainage from the breast is directed to the subclavian lymph nodes.

options.label: C
options.text: Level I lymph nodes are also known as rotter’s nodes.

options.label: D
options.text: Level II lymph nodes are located posterior to the pectoralis major

questions.correct_answer: D. Level II lymph nodes are located posterior to the pectoralis major
questions.explanation:
Level of node

Location

Level I

Lateral to the lateral border of pectoralis minor

Level II(Rotter/Interpectoral nodes)

Anterior as well as posterior to the pectoralis minor and posterior to the pectoralis major.

Level III

Medial to the pectoralis minor muscle and include subclavicular nodes

questions.text: Arrange the following in decreasing order of frequency of metastasis in breast cancer

options.label: A
options.text: Lumbar vertebrae> femur> thoracic vertebrae> ribs> skull

options.label: B
options.text: Lumbar vertebrae> thoracic vertebrae> ribs> skull> femur

options.label: C
options.text: Thoracic vertebrae>lumbar vertebrae> ribs> skull> femur

options.label: D
options.text: Thoracic vertebrae> femur> lumbar vertebrae> ribs> skull

questions.correct_answer: A. Lumbar vertebrae> femur> thoracic vertebrae> ribs> skull
questions.explanation:
Spread of breast cancer

Local Invasion
  • Tumors invade nearby tissues (skin, chest wall).
  • Inflammatory breast cancer blocks lymphatic vessels(subdermal /superficial), causing peau d'orange, often without a palpable mass, complicating detection.

Lymphatic Spread
  • Cancer cells spread to nearby lymph nodes
  • Positive nodes indicate worse prognosis
  • Axillary nodes (75% drainage)- Axillary nodes: Level I (lateral), Level II (posterior), Level III (medial).
  • Lymph nodes closest to the tumor (level I) are usually affected first, followed by those in the middle (level II) and then the top of the armpit (level III).
  • Internal mammary lymph nodes (5% drainage) - secondary route in 20% of cases.

Hematogenous Spread
  • Cancer cells enter the bloodstream indicating stage IV cancer.
  • Metastasising to distant organs in frequency :
    • Bones> lungs> liver> brain
  • Among bones frequency:
    • Lumbar vertebrae> femur> thoracic vertebrae> ribs> skull (Option A)

Multifocal Growth
  • Cancers may appear as multiple independent foci within the same breast or different quadrants
  • Common in invasive lobular carcinoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is diagnosed with breast cancer. The pathology report shows a 2.5 cm tumor with positive lymph nodes. The tumor is ER-positive, PR-positive, and HER2-negative. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding her prognosis and treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: The tumor size and lymph node status suggest a favorable prognosis

options.label: B
options.text: The hormone receptor status indicates the tumor will not respond to endocrine therapy

options.label: C
options.text: The absence of HER2 overexpression means targeted therapies are the primary treatment option

options.label: D
options.text: The ER-positive status suggests a better prognosis and responsiveness to endocrine therapy

questions.correct_answer: D. The ER-positive status suggests a better prognosis and responsiveness to endocrine therapy
questions.explanation:
Disease factors that influence prognosis

Histologic Subtypes
  • Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC): Prognosis varies by grade and molecular markers.
  • Invasive Lobular Carcinoma (ILC): Intermediate prognosis.
  • Tubular and Mucinous Carcinomas: Best prognosis.
  • Basal-like Breast Cancer: Aggressive, triple-negative, no targeted treatments.
  • Other Subtypes: Medullary, cribriform, papillary, adenoid cystic, metaplastic carcinomas vary in prognosis.

Tumor Size & Lymph Node
  • Pathologic staging (tumor size, lymph nodes) guides prognosis and treatment.
  • Larger tumors and positive lymph nodes = worse prognosis. (Option A)

Molecular Markers
  • Hormone Receptors (ER, PR): ER-positive = better prognosis (Option D), responsive to endocrine therapy. (Option B)
  • HER-2 Status: HER-2 positive = aggressive but treatable with targeted therapies. (Option C)

Patient factors that influence prognosis

Age

Younger, particularly premenopausal women, may have higher local recurrence rates post-surgery, but radiation therapy can reduce this risk.

BRCA Mutation

Generally more aggressive and associated with poorer prognosis.

Family History

A strong family history may indicate inherited susceptibility and potentially worse prognosis.

Prior Breast Cancer History

Previous breast cancer can negatively influence the prognosis of a new diagnosis.

Lifestyle Factors

Obesity and inactivity are linked to increased recurrence risk and may affect overall prognosis.

Treatment Adherence

Non-compliance can worsen prognosis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old premenopausal woman is diagnosed with Lobular Carcinoma In Situ (LCIS) after a breast biopsy. She opts for chemoprevention as her management strategy. Her doctor discusses various medication options with her. Which of the following statements about chemoprevention for LCIS is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Chemoprevention eliminates the risk of developing breast cancer

options.label: B
options.text: Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 25% over 5 years

options.label: C
options.text: Chemoprevention is only effective for the ipsilateral breast

options.label: D
options.text: Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 56% over 5 years

questions.correct_answer: D. Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 56% over 5 years
questions.explanation:
Overview
  • Histologic marker of increased breast cancer risk, not true cancer.
  • It involves an abnormal proliferation of cells within the lobules of the breast without invasion through the basement membrane.
  • Subsequent invasive cancers are predominantly ductal, not lobular
Characteristics
  • Occurs mainly in younger, premenopausal women
  • Typically an incidental finding during biopsy
  • No palpable masses or suspicious mammographic microcalcifications
  • Bilateral
Risk
  • 21.4% chance of developing carcinoma over 35 years
  • 7:1 risk ratio for invasive breast cancer
  • 50% of subsequent carcinomas in contralateral breast
Management
  • Close observation
  • Chemoprevention
    • Medications: Tamoxifen, Raloxifene, or Arimidex
    • Tamoxifen reduces risk by 56% over 5 years
  • Surgical: Bilateral mastectomy (if surgery chosen prophylactically)

Clinical Significance
  • Lifelong breast cancer risk affecting both breasts equally 
  • Risk slightly less than 1% per year

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman undergoes a routine mammogram, which reveals clustered calcifications in her left breast. Further investigation confirms the diagnosis of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The lesion is small, low-grade, and has clear margins. The patient expresses a strong desire to preserve her breast if possible. What is the most appropriate initial treatment approach?
questions.explanation:
Overview
  • Non-invasive breast cancer within milk ducts
  • Does not spread beyond the ductal membrane into the surrounding tissue

Detection
  • Primarily through mammogram (clustered calcifications)
  • Less common: palpable mass, calcifications with density, nipple discharge

Types of DCIS
  • Papillary (Low grade)
  • Cribriform (Low grade)
  • Solid (High grade)
  • Comedo (High grade)
  • Mixed morphology- Most DCIS lesions have

Treatment

  • Mastectomy
    • Near-certain cure rate (98-99% survival)
    • 1-2% lifetime risk of local recurrence
  • Breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy) with radiation
    • Reduces recurrence risk compared to lumpectomy alone (Option B)
  • Breast-conserving surgery alone
    • For specific low-risk cases (Option C)

Adjuvant Therapies
  • Hormonal therapy (e.g., Tamoxifen) (Option A)
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB)
    • Recommended for mastectomy patients
    • Considered in specific breast-conserving surgery cases

questions.text: All of the following are invasive carcinomas except:
questions.explanation:
Invasive Carcinomas
  • Invasive Carcinoma of No Special Type (NST)
  • Special Subtypes of Invasive Carcinoma:
    • Invasive Ductal carcinoma (Option A)
    • Invasive Lobular Carcinoma: Classic, solid, alveolar, pleomorphic, and tubulolobular variants. (Option B)
    • Tubular Carcinoma
    • Cribriform Carcinoma
    • Mucinous Carcinoma: Characterized by mucin production, good prognosis.
    • Medullary Carcinoma: Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, associated with BRCA1 mutations. (Option C)
    • Metaplastic Carcinoma
    • Invasive Micropapillary Carcinoma
    • Carcinomas with Apocrine Differentiation

Precursor Lesions
  • Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS)
  • Lobular Carcinoma In Situ (LCIS)

Benign Epithelial Proliferations
  • Fibroadenomas (Option D)
  • Phyllodes Tumors

Rare Tumor Types
  • Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma
  • Secretory Carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common model used for breast cancer risk assessment?
questions.explanation:
Gail model

Clause model

Most commonly used

More information about family history

Absolute risk estimation

Relative risk estimation

It is assessed with

  • Age at menarche
  • Number of 1st°relatives with breast carcinoma
  • Age at first life birth
  • Number of breast biopsies

It is assessed with

  • 1st° and 2nd° relatives with breast cancer
  • Age of diagnosis of relatives

questions.text: Which of the following statements about breast cancer risk factors is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The median age of breast cancer presentation is 60 years in India

options.label: B
options.text: The relative risk of Papillomatosis is 8-10

options.label: C
options.text: Relative Risk for breast cancer in 1st-degree relative is 3

options.label: D
options.text: Early onset of menstruation increases breast cancer risk.

questions.correct_answer: D. Early onset of menstruation increases breast cancer risk.
questions.explanation:
Modifiable risk factors

Non-modifiable risk factors

Obesity: BMI > 30 (RR= 1.29)

Age

  • Median age at presentation is 60 years in the West(UK,USA) While it is around 48 years in low/middle-income nations such as India.(Option A)

Nulliparous women or first pregnancy after 35 years

Sex

  • Female sex is a risk factor
  • Male sex accounts for 0.5-1% of all breast cancer

Breastfeeding is a protective factor

Ethnicity

American white, African-American Parsi in India

Use of Hormonal Replacement Therapy (HRT) >10 years (RR= 1.2)

Family history of breast cancer

  • 1 first degree relative RR= 2(option C)
  • 2 first-degree relative RR= 3

Tobacco use (RR=1.07-1.14)

Genetic predisposition

BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations account for 70% of hereditary breast cancers

Alcohol Consumption (RR = 1.05-1.32)

Early Menarche(<12years)

Increases by around 5% for each year earlier menstruation begins RR=1.19

Radiation exposure (RR=6)

Late Menopause(>55years)

Increases by about 3% for each year later menopause begins RR=1.12

Age at first child

 
  • <20years - Less risk
  • >35years - High risk

High-risk breast lesions

  • Complex fibroadenoma RR=3
  • Papillomatosis RR=3(Option B)
  • Ductal and lobular hyperplasia RR= 5
  • Lobular carcinoma in situ RR= 8-10

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge?
questions.explanation:
Type of Nipple Discharge

Causes

Bloody
  • Intraductal Papilloma (Most Common)
  • Breast Carcinoma
  • Duct Ectasia

Serous

  • Fibrocystic Disease (Most Common)
  • Breast Carcinoma
  • Duct Ectasia

Greenish/Blackish
  • Duct Ectasia

Milk (Galactorrhea)
  • Physiological (e.g., Pregnancy, Lactation)
  • Hyperprolactinemia (e.g., Pituitary Adenoma, Hypothyroidism)
  • Medications (e.g., Antipsychotics, Antidepressants, Oral Contraceptives)

Purulent
  • Breast Abscess
  • Mastitis

questions.text: What is the primary arterial supply to the superior part of the breast?
questions.explanation:
Artery

Areas Supplied

Internal thoracic artery

Medial and central parts of the breast

Lateral thoracic artery

Lateral aspect of the breast

Thoracoacromial artery

Superior part of the breast

Posterior intercostal arteries

Lateral and posterior aspects of the breast

Superior thoracic artery

Upper part of the breast (limited supply)

Subscapular artery

Lower part of the breast
